text: FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
label: HH1

text: ACQUISITION WORKFORCE WORKING GROUP
label: HH1

text: [As revised and provisionally adopted by the Acquisition Advisory Panel]
label: HH2

text: FINDINGS
label: HH2

text: Finding #1:
label: HH2

text: The federal acquisition workforce is an essential key to success in achieving the government’s
label: BODY

text: missions.  Procurement is an increasingly central part of the government’s activities.  Without a
label: BODY

text: workforce that is qualitatively and quantitatively adequate and adapted to its mission the
label: BODY

text: procurement reforms of the last decade cannot achieve their potential, and successful federal
label: BODY

text: procurement cannot be achieved.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2:
label: HH2

text: Demands on the federal acquisition workforce have grown substantially:
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-1:
label: HH1

text: The dollar volume of federal government procurement has increased
label: BODY

text: dramatically since 9/11/2001.   Procurement obligations have increased 60%
label: BODY

text: in the last five years.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-2:
label: HH1

text: In the last twelve years the qualitative nature of the procurement activity has
label: BODY

text: also changed, placing markedly greater demands on the Acquisition
label: BODY

text: Workforce for capability, training, time, and sophistication.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-2-1:
label: HH1

text: There has been a pronounced shift from acquisition of goods to
label: BODY

text: acquisition of services.  Service contracting places additional demands
label: BODY

text: on the acquisition workforce, both in the requirements definition and
label: BODY

text: contract formation process, particularly in the realm of performance-
label: BODY

text: based service acquisition, but also on the contract management side.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-2-2:
label: HH1

text: There has been a dramatic shift of federal procurement dollars to the
label: BODY

text: federal supply schedules and other forms of interagency contracting.
label: BODY

text: Although this is often perceived, correctly, as part of the solution to
label: BODY

text: the government’s procurement problems and its acquisition workforce
label: BODY

text: shortcomings, it also opens the door to certain problems:
label: BODY

text: – Heavy reliance on the schedules and other forms of interagency
label: BODY

text: contracting can alleviate the burdens on understaffed agencies
label: BODY

text: insofar as “getting to the initial award,” but too often
label: BODY

text: contributes to subsequent problems that arise when ordering
label: BODY

text: agencies fail to define their requirements adequately, fail to use
label: BODY

text: these vehicles appropriately, fail to secure competition in using
label: BODY

text: these vehicles, or fail to manage contract performance under
label: BODY

text: these vehicles.  Some of these problems are more acute with
label: BODY

text: respect to assisting entities as opposed to direct ordering
label: BODY

text: vehicles.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-3:
label: HH1

text: Many transactions have been simplified by the federal acquisition reforms of
label: BODY

text: the last decade.  This is particularly true of the purchase card and the
label: BODY

text: simplified acquisition threshold.  These simplified transactions represent the
label: BODY

text: overwhelming bulk of procurement transactions if we simply count
label: BODY

text: transactions.  However, even the simplified purchase card transactions have a
label: BODY

text: more complex impact on the acquisition workforce than was initially
label: BODY

text: appreciated, because of the need to institute and maintain appropriate
label: BODY

text: purchase card management and controls.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-4:
label: HH1

text: But the remaining share of procurement –outside the ambit of simplified
label: BODY

text: procedures-- is the portion that actually requires most of our attention going
label: BODY

text: forward. For this critical share of the government’s procurement activity, the
label: BODY

text: demands of procurement on the acquisition workforce have grown
label: BODY

text: dramatically.  The changes in our procurement system that produce these
label: BODY

text: demands may be desirable, but they are not cost-free.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-4-1:
label: HH1

text: Procurement outside the simplified regimes is characterized by use of
label: BODY

text: best value procurement procedures, which substantially increase the
label: BODY

text: complexity of procurement and the demands on the acquisition
label: BODY

text: workforce as compared with procurement on the basis of lowest price.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-4-2:
label: HH1

text: Procurement outside the simplified regimes is subject to requirements
label: BODY

text: of past performance evaluation which substantially increase the
label: BODY

text: burdens of procurement on the acquisition workforce.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-4-3
label: HH1

text: A substantial share of procurement outside the simplified regimes is
label: BODY

text: performance-based services acquisition, which dramatically increases
label: BODY

text: the complexity and burden of demands imposed on the federal
label: BODY

text: acquisition workforce.
label: BODY

text: Finding #2-4-3
label: HH1

text: A substantial share of procurement outside the simplified regimes is
label: BODY

text: performance-based services acquisition, which dramatically increases
label: BODY

text: the complexity and burden of demands imposed on the federal
label: BODY

text: acquisition workforce.
label: BODY

text: Finding #3:
label: HH2

text: Even though there are now available a variety of simplified acquisition techniques, the
label: BODY

text: complexity of the federal acquisition system as a whole has markedly increased since the 1980s.
label: BODY

text: Procurement reforms designed to accelerate mission accomplishment nonetheless  burden
label: BODY

text: the acquisition workforce, which needs to choose among available
label: BODY

text: techniques. There are
label: BODY

text: difficult decisions to about when to use which approach.
label: BODY

text: The acquisition workforce also needs to be equipped to exercise discretion in
label: BODY

text: choosing the appropriate procedure for procurement.
label: BODY

text: While some procurement functions can be performed satisfactorily by personnel  with
label: BODY

text: mastery only over the simplified techniques, more complex federal
label: BODY

text: acquisitions demand
label: BODY

text: procurement personnel with mastery of the range of
label: BODY

text: procurement techniques.  Thus the
label: BODY

text: complexity of the acquisition system, taken as  a whole, has become a major challenge to
label: BODY

text: the acquisition workforce.
label: BODY

text: Finding #4:
label: HH2

text: There are substantial problems with the data that are available on the federal acquisition
label: BODY

text: workforce.
label: BODY

text: Finding #4-1:
label: HH1

text: Data has not been collected in a consistent fashion from year to year or across
label: BODY

text: agencies
label: BODY

text: Finding #4-2:
label: HH1

text: The acquisition workforce has been defined differently for DoD and for
label: BODY

text: civilian agencies over the period of the acquisition reforms and the acquisition
label: BODY

text: workforce cutbacks that have occurred in the last 15 years.
label: BODY

text: Finding #4-3:
label: HH1

text: A significant policy issue is presented as to how broadly to define the
label: BODY

text: composition of the acquisition workforce—whether to include all of the
label: BODY

text: functions that complement or support the acquisition function?  A broad
label: BODY

text: definition is more consistent with modern understanding and commercial
label: BODY

text: practices regarding the acquisition function, but risks overstating acquisition
label: BODY

text: workforce resources.
label: BODY

text: Finding #5:
label: HH3

text: The Federal Government does not have the capacity in its current acquisition workforce
label: BODY

text: necessary to meet the demands that have been placed on it.  Because of the absence of human
label: BODY

text: capital planning to date, the Panel cannot definitively conclude whether this is the result of a
label: BODY

text: numbers problem, but has received testimony raising serious concerns about the number, skill
label: BODY

text: sets, deployment, and role in the acquisition process of the acquisition workforce.
label: BODY

text: There were substantial reductions in the acquisition workforce during the decade of the
label: BODY

text: One result of this is that hiring of new acquisition professionals virtually ceased during
label: BODY

text: this time period.
label: BODY

text: Finding #5.1:
label: HH1

text: There were cuts in some agency training budgets in the 1990’s that meant the
label: BODY

text: existing workforce was not trained to adapt to the increasingly complex and
label: BODY

text: demanding environment in which they were called upon to function.
label: BODY

text: Despite recent efforts to devote more attention and funding to workforce
label: BODY

text: training, in many agencies these efforts do not appear to meet the existing and
label: BODY

text: future needs for a trained acquisition workforce
label: BODY

text: Since 1999 the size of the acquisition workforce has remained relatively
label: BODY

text: stable, while the volume and complexity of federal contracting has
label: BODY

text: mushroomed.
label: BODY

text: Finding #5-2:
label: HH1

text: The drought in hiring, the inadequacy of training in some agencies, and the
label: BODY

text: increased demand for contracting have together created a situation in which
label: BODY

text: there is not, in the pipeline, a sufficient cadre of mature acquisition
label: BODY

text: professionals who have the skills and the training to assume responsibility for
label: BODY

text: procurement in today’s demanding environment.
label: BODY

text: Frequently described as a “bathtub” situation, there appears to be an acute
label: BODY

text: shortage of procurement personnel with between 5 and 15 years of
label: BODY

text: experience.
label: BODY

text: Moreover, the relative sufficiency of the senior end of the acquisition
label: BODY

text: workforce, is seriously threatened by retirements.
label: BODY

text: A key challenge, accordingly, is to retain a high proportion of the senior
label: BODY

text: workforce while development of the mid-level workforce goes forward.
label: BODY

text: There is strong competition for a limited and shrinking pool of trained and
label: BODY

text: skilled procurement professionals within the federal government.
label: BODY

text: This imbalance between supply and demand is exacerbated by the strong
label: BODY

text: competition that the private sector offers the government in trying to
label: BODY

text: recruit the shrinking pool of talented procurement professionals.   The
label: BODY

text: government is losing this competition.
label: BODY

text: On the other hand, at least in major metropolitan areas, the government
label: BODY

text: has not been able to compete very successfully for the services of talented
label: BODY

text: procurement professionals who have been working within the private
label: BODY

text: sector.  The government does not have a salary structure and career
label: BODY

text: ladders that are likely to attract experienced procurement professionals
label: BODY

text: from the private sectors.
label: BODY

text: The slowness of the government’s hiring process has also been an obstacle
label: BODY

text: to hiring talented people for the acquisition workforce.
label: BODY

text: Finding #5-3:
label: HH1

text: A widely noted result of the inadequacy of Acquisition Workforce
label: BODY

text: personnel resources to meet the demands of procurement government-
label: BODY

text: wide is that scarce resources have been skewed toward contract formation
label: BODY

text: and away from contract management.
label: BODY

text: Finding #5-4:
label: HH1

text: The Panel concludes that one important way to improve retention of
label: BODY

text: qualified personnel within the federal acquisition workforce is to expand
label: BODY

text: opportunities for such personnel to secure advancement by moving to
label: BODY

text: different organizations within the federal government.
label: BODY

text: Finding #5-5:
label: HH1

text: Inadequacy in the acquisition workforce is, ultimately, “penny wise and
label: BODY

text: pound foolish,” as it seriously undermines the pursuit of good value for
label: BODY

text: the expenditure of public resources.
label: BODY

text: Finding #6:
label: HH2

text: Most federal agencies have not engaged systematically in human capital planning for the federal
label: BODY

text: acquisition workforce.  Few agencies have systematically assessed their acquisition workforce in
label: BODY

text: the present or for the future.
label: BODY

text: Finding #7:
label: HH2

text: Despite the variations in the way the acquisition workforce has been defined and counted over
label: BODY

text: time and among agencies, no one is counting contractor personnel that are used to assist, support
label: BODY

text: and augment the Acquisition Workforce. Thus we lack accurate information about the extent to
label: BODY

text: which acquisition functions have been and are being carried out with the assistance of contractor
label: BODY

text: personnel.
label: BODY

text: Evidence before the panel and the experience of panel members nonetheless makes clear
label: BODY

text: that many agencies make substantial use of contractor resources to carry out their
label: BODY

text: acquisition functions.
label: BODY

text: We also lack information with which to determine whether reliance on contractor
label: BODY

text: personnel is saving money.
label: BODY

text: Finding #8:
label: HH2

text: Use of contractor support for acquisition activities may be appropriate, but careful attention must
label: BODY

text: be paid to the potential for organizational conflicts of interest that may be engendered by this
label: BODY

text: practice.
label: BODY

text: Finding #9-1
label: HH1

text: Testimony before the Acquisition Advisory Panel by leaders of private
label: BODY

text: sector organizations indicates that sophisticated private sector
label: BODY

text: organizations employ a corps of highly sophisticated, highly credentialed
label: BODY

text: and highly trained business managers to carry out the sourcing,
label: BODY

text: procurement and contract management functions that they undertake.
label: BODY

text: Finding #9-2:
label: HH1

text: The government lacks comparable resources for these functions.  If we
label: BODY

text: expect the government to take advantage of the practices of successful
label: BODY

text: commercial organizations, we need to close this gap by recruiting, training
label: BODY

text: and retaining sufficient procurement professionals with appropriate
label: BODY

text: capability.
label: BODY

text: For successful modern businesses, the acquisition function is regarded
label: BODY

text: as a key contributor to the bottom line.  Investment in a state-of-the-art
label: BODY

text: acquisition workforce is essential to profitability.
label: BODY

text: Similarly, investment in a quality federal acquisition workforce is
label: BODY

text: critical to mission success and obtaining best value for the expenditure
label: BODY

text: of public resources.
label: BODY

text: Finding #10:
label: HH3

text: The pace of acquisition reform initiatives has outstripped the ability of the federal acquisition
label: BODY

text: workforce to assimilate and master their requirements so as to implement these initiatives in an
label: BODY

text: optimal fashion. An important objective of Acquisition Workforce initiatives should be to allow
label: BODY

text: the Workforce to catch up with the last twelve years of acquisition reform, as well as to meet
label: BODY

text: additional demands that will be imposed by the recommendations of this panel on non-workforce
label: BODY

text: topics.
label: BODY

text: Insisting that the acquisition workforce be enabled to catch up with the demands of the
label: BODY

text: procurement workload and the transformed demands of procurement reform is not hostile
label: BODY

text: to the cause of procurement reform.  Rather, it is an essential step in attempting
label: BODY

text: consistently to achieve good value for the expenditure of public resources.
label: BODY

text: Investment in the acquisition workforce should therefore yield an extremely rewarding
label: BODY

text: return on that investment.
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDTIONS
label: HH2

text: Recommendation #1-1: Data Collection and Workforce Definition
label: HH2

text: OFPP needs to ensure, going forward, that consistent and sensible definitions of the
label: BODY

text: acquisition workforce are in place, and that accurate data is consistently collected about
label: BODY

text: all of the relevant categories, from year to year and across all agencies.
label: BODY

text: Data should be collected both about the narrow contracting specialties (along the lines of
label: BODY

text: the current FAI count) and about the broader acquisition-related workforce (along the
label: BODY

text: lines of the current DoD AT&L workforce count methodology).
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #1-2: Data Collection and Workforce Definition
label: HH2

text: The Office of Federal Procurement Policy should prescribe a consistent definition and a
label: BODY

text: method for measuring the Acquisition Workforce of both civilian and military agencies.
label: BODY

text: Definitions and measures should be completed by OFPP within 1 year from the date of
label: BODY

text: this report.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #1-3: Acquisition Workforce Database [Tabled]
label: HH2

text: OFPP should find a means of consistently measuring the contribution of contractor
label: BODY

text: personnel to the work of acquisition. [TABLED – to be considered by the Appropriate
label: BODY

text: Role of Contractors Supporting the Government Working Group in its discussion of
label: BODY

text: personal services contracts]
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #1.4: Acquisition Workforce Database
label: HH2

text: Consistent with recommendations 1-1 and 1-2, OFPP should be responsible for the
label: BODY

text: creation, implementation, and maintenance of a mandatory single government-wide
label: BODY

text: database for members of the Acquisition Workforce
label: BODY

text: – The database should reflect the following purpose and elements:
label: BODY

text: Purpose: To provide information to support effective human capital
label: BODY

text: management of the acquisition workforce
label: BODY

text: Elements should include: employment experience, education, training,
label: BODY

text: certifications, grade, pay, career series, and retirement eligibility.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #2-1: Human Capital Planning for the Acquisition Workforce
label: HH2

text: In each agency, as part of the overall agency Human Capital Management Plan, the Chief
label: BODY

text: Acquisition Officer should be responsible for creating and implementing a distinct
label: BODY

text: Acquisition Workforce Human Capital Strategic Plan designed to assess and meet the
label: BODY

text: agency’s needs for acquisition workforce.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #2-2: Human Capital Planning for the Acquisition Workforce
label: HH3

text: Agency CAOs should be responsible for measuring and predicting, to the extent possible,
label: BODY

text: the agency’s needs for procurement personnel.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #2-3: Human Capital Planning for the Acquisition Workforce
label: HH2

text: It is not sufficient simply to try to retain and manage existing personnel resources.
label: BODY

text: Resources needed must be identified and gaps between needed resources and available
label: BODY

text: resources must be forthrightly acknowledged.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #2-4: Human Capital Planning for the Acquisition Workforce
label: HH2

text: Assessment of the role played by contractor personnel in the acquisition workforce
label: BODY

text: should be part of the strategic plan.
label: BODY

text: The strategic plan should consider whether the current use of contractor personnel to
label: BODY

text: supplement the acquisition workforce is efficient or not.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #2-5: Qualitative Assessment
label: HH2

text: Agencies’ human capital planning for the acquisition workforce needs to address the
label: BODY

text: adequacy of existing resources in meeting each agency’s procurement needs throughout
label: BODY

text: the acquisition lifecycle.  The standard should be whether the government is able to
label: BODY

text: optimize the contribution of private sector capabilities, secured through the market, to the
label: BODY

text: accomplishment of federal agency missions.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #3: Workforce Improvements Need Prompt Attention
label: HH2

text: Due to the severe lack of capacity in the acquisition workforce, aggressive action to improve the
label: BODY

text: acquisition workforce must begin immediately.  All agencies should begin acquisition workforce
label: BODY

text: human capital planning immediately, if such plans are not already underway.  Agencies should
label: BODY

text: complete initial assessment and planning as quickly as possible.  If initial human capital planning
label: BODY

text: reveals gaps, agencies should take immediate steps to address such gaps, whether they arise in
label: BODY

text: hiring, allocation of resources, training or otherwise.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #3-1: Need to Recruit Talented Entry Level Personnel
label: HH2

text: OFPP should establish a government-wide acquisition internship program to attract first
label: BODY

text: rate entry level personnel into acquisition careers.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #3-2: Hiring Streamlining Necessary
label: HH3

text: In order to compete effectively for desirable personnel, OFPP and agencies need to
label: BODY

text: identify and eliminate obstacles to speedy hiring of acquisition workforce personnel.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #3-3: Need to Retain Senior Workforce
label: HH2

text: OFPP and agencies need to create and use incentives for qualified senior, experienced
label: BODY

text: acquisition workforce personnel to remain in the acquisition workforce.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #3-4: Training
label: HH2

text: In order to ensure the availability of sufficient funds to provide training to the Acquisition
label: BODY

text: Workforce OMB should issue guidance directing agencies to:
label: BODY

text: Assure that funds in agency budgets identified for Acquisition Workforce training are
label: BODY

text: actually expended for workforce training purposes, by appropriate means including
label: BODY

text: “fencing” of those funds.
label: BODY

text: Require Head of Agency approval for use of workforce training funds for any other
label: BODY

text: purpose
label: BODY

text: Provide OFPP an annual report on the expenditure of Acquisition Workforce Training
label: BODY

text: Funds identifying any excesses or shortfalls
label: BODY

text: OFPP should conduct an annual review to determine whether the funds identified by each
label: BODY

text: agency for training of its acquisition workforce are sufficient to meet the agency’s needs
label: BODY

text: for acquisition workforce training. Once an agency’s human capital strategic plan for the
label: BODY

text: acquisition workforce is in place, that plan should guide this determination.  OFPP’s
label: BODY

text: review should also ascertain whether funds identified for such training were actually
label: BODY

text: expended for Acquisition Workforce training needs.
label: BODY

text: Congress should reauthorize the SARA Training Fund and provide direct
label: BODY

text: funding/appropriations for the fund.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #3-5: Acquisition Workforce Education & Training Requirements
label: HH2

text: Currently both DAWIA and Clinger-Cohen provide for waivers to Congressionally
label: BODY

text: established education and training requirements.  In order to ensure that the government’s
label: BODY

text: Acquisition Workforce has both the competencies and skills to manage the life-cycle of
label: BODY

text: the acquisition process
label: BODY

text: Agencies should only grant permanent waivers to education and training requirements
label: BODY

text: upon an objective demonstration that the grantee of the waiver possesses the
label: BODY

text: competencies and skills necessary to perform his/her duties.
label: BODY

text: Agencies should only grant temporary waivers to allow the grantee of the waiver
label: BODY

text: sufficient time to acquire the lacking education or training
label: BODY

text: Agency CAOs (or equivalent) should report annually to OFPP on the agency’s usage
label: BODY

text: of waivers to meet statutory training and education requirements, justifying their
label: BODY

text: usage consistent with the foregoing requirements, and reporting on plans to overcome
label: BODY

text: the need to rely excessively on waivers
label: BODY

text: OFPP should review these annual reports, and provide annual summary report on the
label: BODY

text: use of waivers of DAWIA and Clinger-Cohen requirements.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation (Adopted but remains to be numbered)
label: HH2

text: To the extent that agencies can demonstrate that they have implemented any
label: BODY

text: recommendations (or parts thereof) that require a report to OFPP, the process established
label: BODY

text: by OFPP should include criteria for a waiver from the reporting requirements; any waiver
label: BODY

text: should include a requirement for a sunset.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #3.6: Acquisition Workforce University
label: HH2

text: In order to promote consistent quality, efficiency and effectiveness in the use of
label: BODY

text: government training funds, OFPP should convene a 12 month study panel to consider
label: BODY

text: whether to establish a government-wide Federal Acquisition University and/or alternative
label: BODY

text: recommendations to improve training.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #4: An Acquisition Workforce Focus is Needed in OFPP
label: HH2

text: There should be established in the Office of Federal Procurement Policy a senior executive
label: BODY

text: with responsibility for Acquisition Workforce Policy throughout the federal government.
label: BODY

text: As part of OMB’s role in reviewing and approving agency Human Capital Plans in
label: BODY

text: conjunction with OPM, OFPP should be delegated responsibility for receiving and reviewing
label: BODY

text: the agency Acquisition Workforce Human Capital Strategic Plans, and for identifying trends,
label: BODY

text: good practices and shortcomings.
label: BODY

text: The following Recommendations were deferred to the “Appropriate Role of Contractors
label: HH2

text: Supporting the Government” Working Group
label: HH2

text: Recommendation #5-1: Blended Workforce
label: HH2

text: Consistent with the framework of the findings and recommendations of the Appropriate
label: BODY

text: Role working group, agencies need to retain the core capabilities to:
label: BODY

text: – Determine their requirements
label: BODY

text: – Select contractors
label: BODY

text: – Oversee contract performance
label: BODY

text: [Deferred to Appropriate Role WG]
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #5-2: Blended Workforce
label: HH2

text: Contractors can supplement the resources of agencies in performing their acquisition
label: BODY

text: functions, but must not
label: BODY

text: – Infringe the core functions noted above
label: BODY

text: – Act in areas that create a conflict of interest for the organizations involved, or for
label: BODY

text: individual personnel
label: BODY

text: [Deferred to Appropriate Role WG]
label: BODY

text: Recommendation #5-3: Blended Workforce
label: HH2

text: Agencies must have in place affirmative safeguards to assure that supplementation of the
label: BODY

text: Acquisition Workforce with contractor support does not create organizational conflicts of
label: BODY

text: interest.
label: BODY

text: [Deferred to Appropriate Role WG]
label: BODY
